title: Make automatic HEAD -> GET configurable
body: The automatic conversion of `HEAD` requests to `GET` requests when there is no HEAD method in the route should be configurable (i.e. turn it on or off).

title: Make automatic OPTIONS responses configurable
body: The automatic OPTIONS responses should be configurable (i.e. turn it on or off).

title: Method for bailing out of a router and returning to the previous middleware level
body:
Per conversation with @dougwilson on IRC, it would be very useful to have an equivalent for `next('route')`, but at the router level.  Calling it would cause a router to skip all remaining middleware and routes on that router.

This would allow for conditional execution of middleware, such as session handling and session related middleware only being evoked for users with an existing session cookie.

`next('router')` could work, but that might be too close of terms.

title: Release 5.0
body:
This is a tracking issue for release 5.0.

I am trying to give better visibility for upcoming changes and so am trying out making a PR for a release here, pulling from the official next release branch into 4.x. This allows for the current pending changes to be easily visible.

**Please keep feature requests in their own issues**

I'm also leaving this PR unlocked so people can make comments/etc. and we'll see how it goes :) If you want to make a comment on a particular change, please make the comment in the "Files changed" tab so comments are not lost during a rebase (they will occur frequently has 4.x progresses).

List of changes for release:
- [ ] Add support for Promises in all handlers #2259
- [x] Bring back `app.router` which is just generally useful for directly calling to the router
  - [ ] Make sure 3.x-style `app.use(app.router)` does not explode
- [x] Make `req.host` actually return the host #2179
- [x] Make `req.query` a getter instead of added by middleware #2215
- [ ] Make `res.sendFile` use the `"etag"` application setting #2294
- [ ] Make `express.static` use the `"etag"` application setting #2317
- [ ] New path matching syntax #2057 #2173
- [ ] Use `mime-types` instead of `mime`

List of deprecated things removed:
- [x] `app.del`
- [x] `req.acceptsCharset`
- [x] `req.acceptsEncoding`
- [x] `req.acceptsLanguage`
- [x] `res.json(obj, status)`
- [x] `res.jsonp(obj, status)`
- [x] `res.send(body, status)`
- [x] `res.send(status)`
- [x] `res.sendfile`
- [ ] `res.vary()` (i.e. no arguments)

List of things to refactor (still provided by `express`):
- [ ] Better `res.cookie` and general cookie reading/setting (new `keygrip` and `cookies` modules)
- [ ] Have router use `path-match` extraction instead of `path-to-regexp` directly
- [ ] Move all related logic using `proxy-addr` to new module (ex `host`, `ip`, etc.) https://github.com/expressjs/proxy-addr/issues/2
- [ ] Move prototype properties to own repo #2432
- [ ] Move `Router` to it's own repo #2411
- [ ] Move `View` and related to own repo #2217

**Testing this release**

If you want to try out this release, you can install it with the following command:
```bash
$ npm install visionmedia/express#5.0
```

Owners/collaborators: please do not merge this PR :)

title: Release 4.7
body:
This is a tracking issue for release 4.7.

I am trying to give better visibility for upcoming changes and so am trying out making a PR for a release here, pulling from the official next release branch into master. This allows for the current pending changes to be easily visible.

**Please keep feature requests in their own issues**

I'm also leaving this PR unlocked so people can make comments/etc. and we'll see how it goes :) If you want to make a comment on a particular change, please make the comment in the "Files changed" tab so comments are not lost during a rebase.

List of changes for release:
- [x] Add Korean documentation #2242 #2244
- [x] Deprecate `res.send(status, body)` format #2227
- [x] Fix errors/hangs sending 500/404 if request had body https://github.com/expressjs/finalhandler/commit/00633b4186ca4d7f6ca91d5c8c04db7bddd8ec24
- [x] Fix `req.protocol` for proxy-direct connections #2252
- [x] Make `req.query` parsing configurable #2215

**Testing this release**

If you want to try out this release, you can install it with the following command:
```bash
$ npm install visionmedia/express#4.7
```

You can also directly reference it in your `package.json`:
```
"dependencies": {
  "express": "visionmedia/express#4.7"
}
```

Owners/collaborators: please do not merge this PR :)

title: Deprecate res.send(status, body) format
body:
This is a discussion regarding the possibility of deprecating `res.send(status, body)` and other methods (`json`, `jsonp` to name some) that do the same thing, where there is an optional first status argument.

Specifically, deprecating the optional `status` as a first argument thing.

/cc @defunctzombie

title: refactor router
body:
we were planning to do this in v4 but we never got around to it. @mscdex has been working on optimizing it and says he's gotten an 80% improvement so far. i guess this is the repo: https://github.com/mscdex/express-optimized

he says it may not be totally backwards compatible, so we'll see what we can do

title: refactor view engine
body:
it shoudl just be in its own library. i quickly hacked together https://github.com/expressjs/templation. some opinions would be nice.

a really good view engine is https://github.com/ericf/express3-handlebars, but the one express includes should be able to use most templating languages

title: remove .get() and .set() functions for settings
body: and just do `app.viewEngine=` and stuff instead

title: remove acceptance tests
body: kind of noisy imo. most of the tests should be integrated into express's tests somehow. we should just move them into a `expressjs/examples` repo or something.

title: Add bodyParser back to express 4.x
body: We have removed all the middlewares from being bundled with express (which is awesome, i.m.o), but left one: `static`. I think we really should bundle `bodyParser` again, because I think parsing bodies is probably even more common than serving static files and many people really have no idea how to read the body from `IncomingMessage` objects (aka `req`) in Node.js core for whatever reason.

title: Include DTrace probes
body:
It would be interesting to include a DTrace provider and some probes to express, in a similar way as it is already implemented in other frameworks such as [resitfy](https://github.com/mcavage/node-restify/search?q=dtrace):
- 'route-start': // server_name, route_name, id, method, url, headers (json)
- 'handler-start': // server_name, route_name, handler_name, id
- 'handler-done': // server_name, route_name, handler_name, id
- 'route-done': // server_name, route_name, id, statusCode, headers (json)

Express users could take advantage of these probes in DTrace-enabled operating systems  (OSX, Solaris, SmartOS, Oracle Linux, BSD...).

Are you open to contributions in this line?

title: Update path regexp functionality
body:
* Old asterisk functionality is obsolete
* Adds the repeated parameters mentioned in visionmedia/express#2134

This will break backward compatibility

title: Params registered on app available in routers used by app
mock requests and routing
body:
Hi,

Has anyone used https://github.com/howardabrams/node-mocks-http with express? I can pass the fake req/res objects to a specific handler but what I'd really like to do is inject them into Express' routing system so that Express chooses the correct handler for me based on the input, and also parses out the URL into params, etc. Maybe there are some internal Express hooks that I can start from?

Thanks!

title: 4.x vs 3.x performance benchmarks?
body:
Looks like there might be a (small) latency hit from switching to v3.x to v4.x around 100req/s:

```
$ bin/flod -c 100..400 -n 10000 examples/express\@3.2.4/index.js examples/express\@4.1.2/index.js 
This is Flod, version 0.2.2
Copyright 2013 Walmart, http://github.com/spumko/flod

Benchmarking (hold on)...

Server         Requests/sec  Latency (ms)     Memory    Load       
-------------  ------------  ---------------  --------  -----------
express@3.2.4  100           43.04 ± 8.39     64M ± 7M  1.89 ± 0.23
express@3.2.4  200           111.72 ± 25.42   65M ± 7M  1.62 ± 0.14
express@3.2.4  300           222.78 ± 40.36   68M ± 7M  1.87 ± 0.15
express@3.2.4  400           485.58 ± 120.50  67M ± 7M  2.21 ± 0.32
express@4.1.2  100           61.01 ± 43.82    66M ± 6M  1.92 ± 0.37
express@4.1.2  200           109.92 ± 19.00   67M ± 7M  1.79 ± 0.09
express@4.1.2  300           241.53 ± 54.77   67M ± 7M  1.82 ± 0.12
express@4.1.2  400           458.87 ± 187.46  68M ± 7M  2.19 ± 0.22
```

Would be nice to publish performance benchmark along every minor release.

title: Redirect inside Router is not relative
Adds support for replacer in json/jsonp calls
Router based redirect bugs
body:
I'm trying to have a router redirect based on it's mount point.

This router
```
var adminRouter = express.Router();
adminRouter.get("/", function(req,res){res.redirect("index");});
app.use("/admin", adminRouter);
```
correctly redirects from /admin/ to /index but redirects /admin to /index.

I tried adding 
```
adminRouter.get("", function(req,res){res.redirect("index");});
```
but /admin still redirects to /index.

Weirdly, an absolute redirect
```
adminRouter.get("/", function(req,res){res.redirect("/admin/index");});
```
correctly redirects /admin to /admin/index.

Nested paths also present problem with routers being unaware of their mount point
```
adminRouter.get("/foo/bar", function(req,res){res.redirect("index");});
```
redirects /admin/foo/bar to /admin/foo/index.

And 
```
adminRouter.get("/foo/bar", function(req,res){res.redirect("/index");});
```
redirects /admin/foo/bar to /index.

title: Path matching semantics update
body:
I would like to make a breaking change update to the way paths match, but I'm interested in everyones opinions before I implement any changes. My biggest gripe right now is that the special characters outside of a custom matching group restricts the characters that can be used inside of a matching group. I want to change this behaviour so only regex characters can be used inside a matching group and characters outside will be escaped.

Examples:

* `/test?` - currently valid, makes the `t` character optional which really look like a bug
* `/:test(.*)` - currently invalid, periods are being escaped and asterisks are being turned into matching any character groups
* `/(\\d+)` - currently won't be indexed properly since we don't have any regex group logic
* `/\\*` - currently invalid, can't escape the meaning of special characters and will still become a match all route

title: 4.x strict routing not enforced via .use()
Is app.route() broken in last commits?
body:
I was using RC1 of 4.0, and my code worked fine. But now im getting:

```
app.route('/').get(controllers.posts.list);
      ^
TypeError: Property 'route' of object function app(req, res, next){ app.handle(req, res, next); } is not a function
```

I didn't change anything (i can be wrong), i just had to reinstall the node_modules directory and express is now latest version (RC4).

If i do `console.log(app.route)` im getting "/" (So... is not a function). Any idea? What i'm doing wrong here?

Thanks in advance.

title: req.query.param_name returns undefined.
body:
I am currently running an Express 4.x project.

Whenever I am trying to access the query parameters through req.query.param (e.g. req.query.offset) a value of undefined is returned. However when I run req.query() the expected query string is returned offset=0

Is there something I am not adding to my application or am I using req.query incorrectly?

title: Please add app.route('foo').use()
body: For Express 4.x, documentation says "Using app.route() is a recommended approach to avoiding duplicate route naming and thus typo errors." However, since all() and use() are different, it would be nice to be able to call use() on route objects as well, to avoid duplicate route naming.

title: deprecate app.render (make private)
body: First step in isolating the view system away from "app" level and towards something that can be used via middleware later.

title: Getter for req.port
body: Complimentary to `req.host`.

title: *.svgz files not supported?
body:
I'm not sure, but when I use *.svgz (compressed svg files) I get the following error:

    This page contains the following errors:
    error on line 1 at column 1: Encoding error
    Below is a rendering of the page up to the first error.

*.svg files work.

On Apache I must add the following line in the .htaccess file to work with .svgz files:

    AddType image/svg+xml      svg svgz
    AddEncoding gzip               svgz

Is there a similar function in express or support express it principle not?

title: Express does not return HTTP 405 when the method is not allowed.
body:
This issue is similar to #1499, but that was closed with the implementation apparently only partially fixed.

When a URL is not handled at all, then 404 is the correct status, because Express does not know of a resource at that URL.

However when a URL is handled, but with a different method (i.e. has a GET handler, but not a POST handler), then Express does know of a resource at this location, but does not know how to handle this particular method. In this case, a 405 is the correct status code.

The previous issue was closed with a comment saying it is a matter of opinion, but I don't think it is, I think Express is currently not following the specification correctly, and it's currently up to developers to add code to conform properly. I think it is reasonable for developers to expect and assume that their framework will do this for them.

Support for this was added to 'express-subroute', but as this is an incorrect handling of the HTTP spec, the functionality for returning 405s should really be in Express core, and not rely on developers finding a separate package, and adding extra functionality with it that they don't need.

title: CookieParser vs req.cookies
body:
When I read about [req.cookies] [1] in expressjs docs, it says

> When the cookieParser() middleware is used this object defaults to {}, otherwise contains the cookies sent by the user-agent.

And when I read about [CookieParser middleware] [2], it says

> Parses the Cookie header field and populates req.cookies with an object keyed by the cookie names.

So, `req.cookies` says if I use CookieParser, it will be set to `{}`, but CookieParser says it will populate `req.cookies`. Sounds confusing to me.

My question is, why do we need CookieParser, if req.cookies itself gives the cookies? I asked [this question] [3] in stackoverflow also.

   [1]: http://expressjs.com/api.html#req.cookies
   [2]: http://expressjs.com/api.html#cookieParser
   [3]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20550656/cookieparser-vs-req-cookies-expressjs
